text: CAROLE M. PFEFFERKORN, the witness herein, having first been duly sworn on oath, was examined and testified as follows:
Ma'am, good morning.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Good morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My name is Scott Chambers, and I represent Connie Richard and her husband in a case currently pending in the Superior Court.  Obviously you're here for a deposition. Have you ever given a deposition before?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's really not that complicated. Just really a question-and-answer session. The only thing I will bring to your attention is we have a court reporter to my left, your right, who's going to be taking down verbatim the things that we talk about today. To keep her job a little easier, will you try to avoid having two of us talk at once?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Second thing is if you could verbalize your answers instead of nodding your head and saying "uh-huh" like we normally do, that would be most appreciated. I don't have very many questions for you, but if at any point you need to take a break or anything, just let us know.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You're an employee of Faw Casson?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What do you do there?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I'm the receptionist.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long have you been the receptionist there?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Nine years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That means you were the receptionist at the time of this incident back on January 9th of 2018?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Connie Richard, I understand, is a client of Faw Casson, or was?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you know her prior to January 9th?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Of the incident?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes, ma'am.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Yes.  As a client, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you know her outside of being a client?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I understand that the day this happened Faw Casson was hosting some type of a seminar on the new tax bill?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let me show you what's been previously marked as Anstine No. 2.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I ask you:  Do you recognize that?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I probably saw it at some point before the function, but it was two years ago, so it's not, like, coming right to recollection.  But yes, I was aware there was a function that morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We have had some testimony about this earlier. It appears that the doors were set to open at 7:30?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: According to this, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the actual event was from 8:00 to 9:00?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It is from Tammy Ordway. Who is she?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: She is one of the partners there that would have headed up this particular session.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: She's a CPA there?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I know it says sent to undisclosed recipients, but do you believe that to be probably to clients of Faw Casson?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The allegation in this case is that my client fell at about 7:30 in the morning. Where were you that morning at 7:30?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: The office is on the second floor. So I was at my front desk, and I would have just been sitting there doing my job.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you were in the building at the time she alleges she fell?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What do you recall about the conditions outside when you arrived that morning?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: The ground would have been salted and it would not have been slick, because if it was, I would have called and taken the necessary action and called the owner of the building and let him know so he could take the actions that he needed to in order to correct it or remedy the problem.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What time did you arrive?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Honestly I can't remember, but I would have been there -- I know I was there when this occurred because someone came up and told me.  But I don't know what time I would have arrived that morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have a specific recollection that it had been salted before this incident?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: When I came in, it was salted.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The reason I ask --
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: In relation to this, I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you certain what time you arrived?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I am not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'll represent to you there's been testimony from the people who did the salting that it had not been salted prior to her fall. Do you have reason to disagree with that?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: If it had not been salted, it was not slick to an extent that I would have called him and said, The sidewalks are slick.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let me show you what's been marked previously as Crissman No. 2.  I ask you to take a look at that. Going down, if you could, to the bottom note, I'll represent to you this is an invoice that was sent to the property manager from Crissman.  And I'm going to have to turn this over because I only have one copy of this. Do you remember whether it was raining when you arrived?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I do not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This indicates:  "Rain began around 4 am.  It continued to rain until roughly 6:30-7." Do you see that?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then it says "When rain subsided we then began to apply salt and melt."  And then it goes on:  "Conditions from 7:30 to 10:30 in Dover were extremely slick, black ice was everywhere." Do you recall whether it was extremely slick and there was black ice everywhere?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I'm upstairs on the second floor, so once I arrive at the office, I would not be back downstairs in order for me to say what the conditions were.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you can't say one way or the other?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you arrive do you go in the front door?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have to use a card to get into the building?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: There is a card reader that, if the doors are not unlocked, yes, you have to use it.  That day in particular I don't remember what time I got there, so I don't know whether I would have needed to use it or not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But it's clear that the plan was that the doors would be open at 7:30 so your clients could come in?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I would have to say yes.  If that is what is on the documentation, then yes, we would have had the door open at that time, but I was not there to confirm or deny that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who was actually conducting the seminar?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: That would have been Tammy Ordway.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was she present?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I could not tell you.  I don't recollect if I was there at the time that this whole thing started.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recollect anyone other than yourself being there that morning?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I do not, because it's been two years ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who attended the meeting that morning?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: John Smith and Sal Minella.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who told you?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I do not recollect.  I just know someone came up and said someone had fallen and that the area was icy and I then reached out to the owner.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you ever have any contact with Ms. Richard?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You never went outside that day?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But after she fell, the person you don't know who it was made you aware that it was icy?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Such that you took it upon yourself to call someone?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who did you call?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Jon Anstine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember what time that was?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I do not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you speak to him, or did you have to leave a message?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I don't recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Anstine has previously testified, and he had actually prepared a timeline for the events on that morning. Take a look at that.  I only have one question about it for you when you're done. That log doesn't appear to reference any messages or calls from you or anyone at Faw Casson. Would you agree?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Objection to form. The second line exactly represents --
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: May I see that?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Second line -- oh.  I stand corrected.  There is your name.  I apologize. It says there's an email from you.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: That's what that states.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall making a phone call?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: The recollection is, like I said, two years ago, so I can't say one way or the other, but I would typically have called him on an incident like that.  I would not have sent an email.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I apologize.  I did not see that entry earlier. The purpose of your call or email, whichever it was, was to inform him it was icy outside?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You did not speak to Ms. Richard that day I know. Have you ever had occasion to speak with her about this incident since then?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I don't believe I have spoken to her about this incident at all, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think that's all I have for you.  Thank you.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Ma'am, you mentioned earlier that you would have called someone if you had any issues getting into the building when you first got there, whenever that was, correct?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: I would have called --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  If you had issues.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Yes.  If it had been slick when I arrived at the office, yes, I would have called.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who would that have been?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: That would have been Jon Anstine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You didn't make the call because you didn't have any issues getting in?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You weren't aware of any issues coming in from anybody else?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were then shown that memo.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Scott, can you hand that back to her?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: The timeline?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Yes, please.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: The timeline is marked as Anstine --
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Anstine 1.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.  If you turn to the second page, that appears to be a copy of the email you sent, but tell me if I'm wrong.  I don't know if that's your email address or not.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: That is my email address.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It reflects that you sent the email on January 9th, 2018, at 8:04 a.m.?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To Mr. Anstine?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You can read that to yourself if you want first.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does that help you recall what you did that morning in terms of notifying Mr. Anstine once you found out there were some issues?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Apparently it was an email?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Yes.  I would have to say I can't recollect, obviously, like I said, two years ago, but I would assume that I probably would have tried to call him and could not get through.  That's why I sent him an email.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say you give him a heads-up, that was for what purpose?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: To make him aware that someone had fallen so if he were to get communications, that he knew what was going on.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know who then would have done any work with regard to outdoor conditions with regard to him?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: I'm not familiar with who the company was, but I know he had someone to come out and -- a company that he would contact to come out and either shovel or put down salt.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ever see anybody doing any work like that at any time that day?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: No, but again, we're on the second floor.  I'm not near a window.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry.  You probably testified to this earlier. Did you actually go down to see --
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- the person or the event?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are there any windows right where you are at the reception area?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You have a statement here in the second sentence of your email about shoveling at the end of the sidewalk where you park. Do you know where that was in relationship to the front entrance where you would have parked that morning?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: In relation to the front entrance, it is quite a ways away.  I don't know how many feet, but it's probably eight car lengths away.  You can park up against the sidewalk there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So is this the sidewalk that leads to the front entrance you're talking about?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was any of the sidewalk clear?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Any of the sidewalk where?
speaker: MR. BAUMBERGER

text: Let me put it this way:  You told us you didn't have any issues getting in. There's a mention here about not shoveling the end of the sidewalk.  I presume from what you have already testified to and the way this email is phrased that some portion of the sidewalk was clear.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Yes.  Because at the end of that, it says "to get to the clear sidewalk."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember where in the parking lot itself it was slippery?  You make a statement in parentheses at the end of that second sentence:  "(which is very slippery still)," and I'm trying to figure out when you were referring to that or when you had that information.  If you know sitting here today.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: That would be the blacktop because I'm stating that "everyone has to walk through the parking lot," which would be the blacktop portion where you would park on, "is very slippery."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you're saying "slippery still," when are you talking about?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: When I was coming in that morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you're not talking about, like, sometime after she fell.  You're talking about when you came in that morning?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You didn't make any calls after coming in that morning to anybody or to Mr. Anstine before this call at 8:00 -- or this email at 8:04; is that correct?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Like I said, this was two years ago, so I can't say for certain, but I would assume out of my typical habit I would have tried to reach out to him via phone and then sent the email.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  But I'm talking about your earlier testimony that, when you first came in that day, you did not call anyone because you didn't have any problems coming in. Is that correct?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you aware of any warnings for late school openings or DOT warnings with regard to travel that morning?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Two years ago.  I couldn't tell you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I had to ask.  I don't know if I don't ask.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Thank you, ma'am. That's all I have for now.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Mary Sherlock.  I represent Crissman Cutters, the snow-and-ice-removal company.  I just have a few questions for you, ma'am. In general terms in January 2018, what would be your normal business hours to arrive there in the morning?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: I normally arrive at 8:00 a.m. because that would be our tax-season hours. So I would have been there at 8:00 a.m.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To the best of your recollection, what time did you arrive that particular morning?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: I do not know.  It would have been before 8:00 a.m. so I could have been at my deck at 8:00 a.m. and been able to answer calls.  But I don't know what time I actually arrived at the office that day.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Exhibit No. 2, Anstine 2, in front of you, was an invitation to the accounting firm's customers to an event that day that was going to be from 8:00 to 9:00, and it indicates the doors would be open at 7:30 a.m., correct?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would that be the doors to the building that they could gain access to the building that day at that time?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So is it fair to say you were probably there that day before 7:30?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: Not necessarily.  I'm the receptionist.  And they would not come to where I was.  And there would have been other staff there as Tammy Ordway and so forth.  So they would have been welcomed and greeted by her.  I necessarily wouldn't have had to be there at 7:30.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That was going to be my next question. Other than yourself when you arrived, were there other employees of the accounting firm already there?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: All I can assume, based on this documentation saying when the time was and that Tammy would be hosting it, she was there.  Beyond that I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall if anyone advised you that they had any issues with the condition of the sidewalk that morning in entering the building?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: The only time I remember anything being mentioned, like I said, was when someone came up and made me aware that someone had fallen in the parking lot.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Other than Ms. Richard, you weren't aware of anyone else having any issues getting in that morning?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: Not to my recollection.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Again, this is one of those questions I have to ask. Do you recall approximately how many clients attended this conference that day?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: I do not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the time of this incident, January 9, 2018, what would the building normal hours be for the general public? Not tenants or employees, but the general public.
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: I'm not sure when the actual doors unlock downstairs.  That's something that usually someone else arranges with Jon Anstine if something were to change or whatever.  That's someone else in the office.  That's not something I'm made aware of.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it fair to say that what Faw Casson was holding on January 9th, 2018, was a special event?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To the best of your knowledge, was the property manager notified of this special event that morning?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: If you know.
speaker: MR. BAUMBERGER

text: I can't really speak on that.  I don't know if he was contacted or not.  I didn't personally contact him.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you or someone at Faw Casson have the direct telephone number for Jon Anstine?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you or someone at Faw Casson, if you know, have the direct telephone number for Joe Crissman at Crissman Cutters?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: Not to my knowledge.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I apologize if you have already been asked this. If you or someone at Faw Casson had an issue with the condition of the sidewalk, that it was slippery, who would you contact?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: I would contact Jon Anstine directly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: For the eight years that you have been working there, have you ever seen a warning sign or cone outside the building on the sidewalk warning of any condition of the sidewalk?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: The only time I can say there's been any cones or anything out there has been when they have been working on either the sidewalk, changing lightbulbs, those types of things, where they want to mark off that area so that nobody is going through there so that no one gets harmed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: By "they" you mean the property managers or owners?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: He usually has someone come down on his behalf.  Like, whoever is doing the maintenance or the work, they would put out cones to mark off the area.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: By "he" you mean Jon Anstine?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To the best of your knowledge, did Faw Casson have any salt or melting substance in the office to put out on the sidewalk?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: We do not, because that's not something that is within our contract. That's not something we take care of.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Some commercial buildings and professional buildings in the wintertime have a bag of salt by the front door. Do you know if there was any such salt or ice melt?
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: I did not see that in the past.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, ma'am.  That's all I have.
speaker: MS. SHERLOCK

text: Can I get that exhibit back from you?  I might have one follow-up question.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: If I can summarize what you told us, you're not sure what time you got there that morning.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I do not know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You didn't have any problems coming into the building, correct?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Other than what's stated in that email.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you came in that morning, you noted that it was still very slippery?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: The parking lot, the blacktop, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And it was slippery enough that you sent this email to Mr. Anstine?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: The blacktop was slippery enough that I sent it to Mr. Anstine.  Not the sidewalk.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any explanation as to why one might be slippery and not the other?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: I can't say.  That's a scientific thing.  That's nothing I can say one way or the other.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Ma'am, did you have any involvement in negotiating or doing anything with regard to the lease for the property for Faw Casson?
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: No.  I'm a receptionist.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I just want to make sure.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: Thank you.
speaker: MR. DOSS

text: I just have one question. The email that you sent to Mr. Anstine, was that on your own or after somebody came up and said somebody fell?
speaker: MR. BAUMBERGER

text: This was after someone fell.  My first line I do believe is, yes, "I think someone just fell in the parking lot this morning so I wanted to give you a heads up."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you were basing that on what you were being told as far as what the conditions were outside --
speaker: MR. BAUMBERGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- versus what you experienced?
speaker: MR. BAUMBERGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BAUMBERGER

text: Didn't I understand your earlier testimony to be that the parking lot was slippery when you came in?
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: The asphalt?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes, ma'am.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Yes.  Was slick.  The sidewalk was not slick.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that was based not on what someone else told you but, rather, what you personally observed.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.
speaker: MR. CHAMBERS

text: (Deposition concluded at 12:17 p.m.)

-  -  -  -  - T E S T I M O N Y DEPONENT:  CAROLE M. PFEFFERKORN     PAGE Examination by Mr. Chambers............3 Examination by Mr. Doss...............14 Examination by Ms. Sherlock...........20 Examination by Mr. Chambers...........26 Examination by Mr. Doss...............27 Examination by Mr. Baumberger.........27 Examination by Mr. Chambers...........28

(No exhibits were marked at this time.) Our office will distribute copies of the executed errata sheet to all counsel.  If necessary, you can make additional copies of the errata sheet. Hurley, Registered certify that there came before me on herein, CAROLE M. I further certify that I am not party, or otherwise interested in the event Dated:  January 29, 2020
